advice: The organization needs to be more transparent and communicate internally as well. I cannot comprehend how the organization that was so keen to make me join them in a week for the process suddenly decided to strike down the project completely.
cons: The organization hired me for National Australian Bank (NAB), a pilot process and requested me to join immediately. Their keenness to start the process (induction and training as the team was ready) asap, required me to quit my previous work place without even serving the full notice period. They issued a Letter of Intent (which included CTC, Designation, Work place, Joining Date etc.) stating that I am a part of their workforce and I should resign from my previous job. Inspite of my hesitancy to take such a step without an Offer Letter in hand, I succumbed as it was a good opportunity, great process and reasonable pay hike. Also the major details regarding my work there were shared with me officially in my Letter of Intent and they also made me talk to my manager to give me assurances. But as soon as the date of joining approached and I got in touch with them, they started delaying the date. They kept telling me that I would receive an official mail and call from them the next day. And this "next day" happened for over a week. Later, I get a call from them stating that the project was scrapped.

text: Pros I would have written something here, if there were any pros to add. If Glassdoor gave that option, a negative overall rating is what I'd have gone for. Cons The organization hired me for National Australian Bank (NAB), a pilot process and requested me to join immediately. Their keenness to start the process (induction and training as the team was ready) asap, required me to quit my previous work place without even serving the full notice period. They issued a Letter of Intent (which included CTC, Designation, Work place, Joining Date etc.) stating that I am a part of their workforce and I should resign from my previous job. Inspite of my hesitancy to take such a step without an Offer Letter in hand, I succumbed as it was a good opportunity, great process and reasonable pay hike. Also the major details regarding my work there were shared with me officially in my Letter of Intent and they also made me talk to my manager to give me assurances. But as soon as the date of joining approached and I got in touch with them, they started delaying the date. They kept telling me that I would receive an official mail and call from them the next day. And this "next day" happened for over a week. Later, I get a call from them stating that the project was scrapped. *They made me quit my previous job assuring me that Genpact process was final- the resignation was necessary so as to make sure I do not indulge in dual employment. *They didn't let me finish the Notice period at my previous workplace as the process at Genpact was solely waiting on my joining to initiate. So I had to pay from my pocket for not finishing up the notice. *They did not start with their induction and training as on the date that they had stated. Thus, making me lose my pay from any workplaces for those days. *And finally, they very simply stated that the project was scrapped and would take me for some customer care department in a different location (which is 2 hours from my place, one way) and at an odd hour shift. As per them, they were doing ,me a favour by not making me re-interview for the new customer care process, which from what I have understood required less skill set. And considering the new job location is not easily commutable distance from my place and that too at odd work hours (3 AM) for a profile I did not sign up for, I seriously fail to see the good that they are offering there. And what's more? Ever since that, they have stopped communicating with me. They do not revert to my mails, messages, phone calls... nothing. They very conveniently put me in a soup and have disappeared. I fail to understand how did they come to be such a big brand if this is the way their HR team functions, the management runs. Or is it all just a facade! I would never want to work with such an organization and recommend nobody to take it up either. What happened with me was at the beginning, yours could be after you join or while leaving. You never know! You can never tell! Not with the kind of things that this organization is capable of pulling off. Advice to Management The organization needs to be more transparent and communicate internally as well. I cannot comprehend how the organization that was so keen to make me join them in a week for the process suddenly decided to strike down the project completely. And moreover, stop playing with people's job and their careers. You can very conveniently say a 'sorry' for messing things up, but they still have to fend for themselves and their families and their lives. And if things get faulty at your part, have the decency to provide a solution and not completely go off the radar. That's just plain brutal and insincere.

cons: - Very disorganised.
pros: - Exposure to some exciting projects.
text: Pros - Exposure to some exciting projects.  - Working from home - although that is also a negative as you will find that there is very little 'team' ethos at this company.  - Part of an international network. Although, many things are controlled in the US and India, which means that you are paralysed until they make a decision. Cons - Very disorganised.  - There is little team ethos. Each man is working for himself on his own project.  - When I was there, you could never get a seat in the London office. Reception would email at 9am to tell people to work from home if they can.  - You could never book an office. Either they are booked up weeks in advance or people are using them because they cannot find a seat.  - No clear strategy as to how to move forward.  - Although they sell 'working from home' in reality it means that you are expected to be working all of the time. It was the 4am email message that put a meeting in my diary for 8am that same day that was the final straw for me.  - Pay is not very good and benefits are practically non-existent. Basic auto-enrolment pension for a professional services firm is a joke. Advice to Management Build a team ethos amongst your London staff. If everyone is striving for the same goal you will have a happier and more profitable business.

advice: It was a blunder when Genpact hired 3 assistant managers from Wipro to serve as team leads in Genpact Boeing project. This project started with 70 people and within 24 months nearly 90% of your old employees are gone trust me it is because of these three managers and rest of the Wipro folks came to Genpact. You should have fire this managers way before the resigned themselves you still have time to allocate the remaining Wipro Associates to other projects within Genpact.
cons: The food in cafeteria is mostly garbage. The transportation is not free of cost if you are taking home drops even you work in night shifts. Naturally they don't have and they had never grown the soft skills I charts should pauses in a MNC environment. They don't even know how to give respect when they are talking with women employee. If you are trying to leave Genpact and somehow the HR team of the operation team gets to know about it then they will make sure that your life is a living hell. Don't take any verbal promises from anyone in Genpact they basically are lies. I have seen people who resigned and serving notice periods and then someone from HR promises percentage Hike or promotion. Based on that the employee don't go to there new companies. But be very sure when it comes to fulfill the promise Genpact HR will turn 180° opposite side. In case if you are willing to do this kind of work then make sure you get your revised offer letter or revised salary hike letter within your notice period otherwise the chances are you will never get it.
pros: The interview procedure was quick. I was hired from Pune to work for Hyderabad location. It was just one round interview. Only because I was hired from a different state altogether so the interview procedure was quick and smooth but if I was a candidate from the same location there are multiple rounds of interview. The work life balance in Genpact is pretty cool you are only responsible for your own work unless and until you are at a band 4 level but if you can take initiatives and keep yourself under the radar of senior managers aur assistant vice president then it will do good in your career. Also they give you opportunities Tu change one project to another however make sure before changing to different projects what is going to be your revised CTC and if you are still going to get your monthly bonus for band 5 level. If you don't consider yourself as a big achiever and you really don't need a lot of promotions of growth no one is going to bother you with anything. Your job in Genpact is totally secure and you can expect around 8 to 10 percentage of CTC Hike every year at band 5 level and around 6 - 9 percentage hike every year at band 4 level it depends on your performance.

advice: Please shut down this god awful company and do us all a favor. text: Pros Can't think of any pros Cons So many to share, it's embarrassing. Let me try capturing all (but I am sure I would have missed a few) - 1. Poor Management Team - Management is utterly disorganized. No clue about the business and almost no idea how to deal with people. I have worked both in London and Bangalore and found the situation to be no different 2. Farcical HR institution - The HR institution is merely an extension of the management, clad in the robe of a HR team. They do not provide any answers and in the event of a dispute with management, be assured you will receive no support from the HR. As an example, I had to survive for a few months without pay for no fault of mine and the HR and management did absolutely nothing. 3. Laggard processes - For an organisation claiming black belt expertise, no process is streamlined. Getting something as simple as expenses claimed can take between 30-90 days! Note that expenses get deducted from salary at the end of 90 days. The process of claims from salary is faster than process of expenses being cleared! 4. Lack of interesting opportunities - I was lucky to get one of the few interesting opportunities we had, allowing me to travel, however, majority of the people I've worked with left in frustration. The attrition was as high as 40% because of a lack of career growth. This is clearly a poor reflection on the organisation. 5. Salary structure - Be aware, what you are promised is not what you will get. The structure is in such a manner that you will likely only make 60-70% of what you believed you would get in hand. 6. Benefits - There are absolutely no benefits. Most other organisations offer benefits like cabs, gym discounts, bike rental discounts etc, however, there are no such benefits here. 7. Bonus and Increment - Bonus and increment are laughable. In a year where the company made handsome profits and being rated top performed, I got less than 10% salary hike and less increment than contractually agreed. This was because the division performed poorly (which is a result of poor management than poor work of the employees), clearly the bonus and increment structure is flawed. Advice to Management Please shut down this god awful company and do us all a favor. If you really do want to keep running this organisation, please recognize that people are your biggest assets, restructure the processes top to bottom, change the focus of the HR team to actually help people and finally pay bonuses and increment commensurate to the hard work of the employees.

You will have access to see the processes of big companies as they allow you to go in shadowing in other teams Cons You will be lied to from the beginning. I was an employee in the Romanian branch and the recruiting strategy is to promise big performance bonuses, but they continously cheat you out of these bonuses by setting standards that cannot be met or by changing the bonus criteria constantly. The salaries are not worth the volumes you have to handle and overtime is not paid. Management and HR lie to the employees or pretend that certain things are not happening. That's what I meant with "I think the survey is actually anonymous" - I saw no straightforward way to de-anonymize the results down to the level of a person. We received the invite to the survey with very little time till deadline, I think most of the answers and discussion happened after. That's why I didn't adjust the question, since it wouldnt be useful to my specific situation anyway but would disrupt the lively discussion happening. What I did: I was pretty honest and mentioned negative points, about the same as I told my boss in our last one-on-one. My boss asked me (to late) to be positive: The company was in a difficult situation, he feared that negative voices on the survey would give upper management the idea that all is hopeless and they should cut further losses. This is a small (100 people) company distributed on four continents, nobody knows what's actually going on. When asking this question I was thinking about these political ramifications (but wasn't posting enough info on the company maybe) & and wha upper management likely does with the survey data. In the team with my boss, we were also discussing the actual anonymity and how things like timezones, speech idiosyncracies (English is a second language to all of us in this office) etc. might give upper management a clear idea who wrote what. advice: Have to quickly understand the realities of the market. Freshers and junior members' contribution are very important to the continued success of this organization. Try to retain them by paying them comparable salaries and thus giving them a chance to stay longer and pay you back in a much more meaningful way. You are growing a seedling into a plant and let them become a tree at your own yard. I understand it works for you as you replace the pool of leaving employees with fresh graduates and overall the cost remains low. But I guess you can have much better level of customer delivery if you don't let the good talent good away.
cons: 1) Pay is not great compared to peers which lead to attrition
pros: 1) Great place to learn - people have patience to train freshers who eventually get up-skilled nicely and contribute immensely to the team and company. Only one disclaimer: freshers are expected to put serious efforts to learn, else nothing much is going to be achieved for both sides
text: Pros 1) Great place to learn - people have patience to train freshers who eventually get up-skilled nicely and contribute immensely to the team and company. Only one disclaimer: freshers are expected to put serious efforts to learn, else nothing much is going to be achieved for both sides 2) Great work-life balance 3) There is a lot of flexibility at work - work from home etc. is great, but frankly should be used judiciously as one learns and grows better if he attends office 4) Mostly young and fun people to work with 5) You get to learn multiple things, your breadth of knowledge really improves working here. The reason being the team structures are not too rigid. One can work on a particular thing in a larger team and also can get opportunity to work on other facets of work which the larger team does, if the person is interested. Another reason this aspect of career improvement gets facilitated is because generally people can take an hour or two from their regular work day and learn and discuss stuff from other team members 6) You can give honest feedback to HR, senior management about your reporting manager if things are unfair. Obviously, things may get leaked and people may not like it. But you would not be penalized if your case is genuine. I have come across some instances where such things happened and feedback was given to the manager. The manager would have been pissed off but made serious efforts to improve. All this reflects very well on the cultural maturity of this organization. Cons 1) Pay is not great compared to peers which lead to attrition 2) Politics does happen, but I guess that's common to most of the workplaces. But definitely a negative thing Advice to Management Have to quickly understand the realities of the market. Freshers and junior members' contribution are very important to the continued success of this organization. Try to retain them by paying them comparable salaries and thus giving them a chance to stay longer and pay you back in a much more meaningful way. You are growing a seedling into a plant and let them become a tree at your own yard. I understand it works for you as you replace the pool of leaving employees with fresh graduates and overall the cost remains low. But I guess you can have much better level of customer delivery if you don't let the good talent good away. You cannot have similar pay structures across all teams under Analytics vertical.

advice: Managers are promoted very easily. After stepping into Band 4, people keep getting promotion year after year. But role is same.
cons: Low pay scale: Genpact is always after cost-cutting. They don't even keep disposable glass for drinking water, no stationery. Lol
pros: Transparency: you can contact any person for issue from bottom to top easily.
text: Pros Transparency: you can contact any person for issue from bottom to top easily. Learning: ask your boss to undergo trainings other than you core job. Eg: lean training, presentation skills, green belt, quality sessions, time management, goal setting, Advance excel & much more. Education@work: enroll for professional courses like CFA, Mba & much more etc. But you have to sign up a bond. Wide business & verticals: Genpact is full of opportunities for every minimum qualification. Learn work & move through IJP to different departments & verticals like BFSI, BFS, CPGA & many more. Job security: As Genpact is full of outsourcing business, you don't have to worry about loosing it in future. opportunities are always there. Promotions: Very easy if you don't get involved with negative people. Complete your trainings, be regular, keep good ratings, be motivated. Off the job trainings: if you wish to learn & get exposed directly with clients, Genpact is the right Co. But only when you get new line of business.  Friendly environment: People are friendly, dress code is casual everyday. Many branches: Genpact has 4 branches in Gurgaon. Silokhera, 22AB, Tikri & Phase 5. 1 in Delhi which is DITP, & 1 in Noida. You can join accordingly. Cons Low pay scale: Genpact is always after cost-cutting. They don't even keep disposable glass for drinking water, no stationery. Lol Poor transport: In Gurgaon branches, cabs are usually late. But Noida is better. Poor management: You can find Assistant managers & Sr. Mgrs everywhere in Genpact, AVPs are common. & none of them can motivate you about career. Most Managers are self centred. They treat Band 5A population like slaves. Band 4 enjoys the team fund & do parties & misuse corporate cards. If you complaint they will ask you to have IJP, spoil your ratings, senior will irritate you everyday, give you unnessary work. Work load: Band 5 population is usually pissed off in department where quantative work is done. Night shift sucks & late cabs will make worst. No work & life balance. Mgrs will ask you to do work instead of enrolled training. Associates working in grave yard shift cannot attend training in day shift, impossible ! Managers are deaf they don't understand. No growth in BFSI, only CPGA is growing. You will become process developer in CPGA withing 18 months. But may take 3 yrs in BFSI or more. No basic facilities: I worked as a associate for 3 yrs, I did't even get my ESIC card. HR don't care, they laugh when you ask for ESIC card. I spend thousands on my treatment which can be done free of cost if I had ESIC card. Advice to Management Managers are promoted very easily. After stepping into Band 4, people keep getting promotion year after year. But role is same. Please make a action plan like introducing written subjective exams. I bet most managers will fail. Increase pay scale.

advice: Its a shame, look back 6 years and follow what you used to do, would be an impeccable company to work for.
cons: Training - almost Nil (Cost involved)
pros: Note: The below is from my experience and opinion. Anyone not comfortable, ignore the review and read an other one.
text: Pros Note: The below is from my experience and opinion. Anyone not comfortable, ignore the review and read an other one. The Company is a pioneer BPO, Beware and dont be carried away, The Standard has been a steady decline, it had hit its bottom. Less work pressure, Well, the Pros could have been a lenghthy list, Say Training, employee welfare, however, one couldnt say all those. work stations are ergonomic - Thanks to GE (who build the uppal facility) All processes are easy and can be negotiated with in your 9 hours shift. Lots of dayshft processes - so worth giving a shot. Promotions - Similar to all the companies - politics and favoratism does exists Learning and educational cource offered @ genpact - Well honestly all the companies provide them, nothing significant. I Gotta rate them 2 Star rating instead of 1- as their business model still works with a below par pay structure (Gotta give it to the higher management for the strategies which they had come up with) - it works. Cons Training - almost Nil (Cost involved) Compensation - Way below industry standard Cab facility - Smartly designed (got to give it) coz it discorages employees to use cabs Ambience and comfort in office - A/C wouldnt work most time. (Lobbies it does work, not on the floor) Pray everyday a client visists (As A/C would work when Clients are around as they are humans and we are ?) Most of Middle management - are now below par compared to 5 years earlier ( why, they all moved to other companies) and hence a very mediocre standard and knowledge. "You get what you pay for" Team outings and other activities where cost is involved - Forget it Few companies would recruit you one level below Genpact Designation (be aware) The design of GE - GECIS and DNA of 6 Sigma has disappeared. Ask any one who joined post 2006, they would be oblivious to this. One of the cornerstones of Genpact "Integrity" is very questionable when comes to information transfer between Management and Customers.( This is sensitive and leagal - Cant explain ) Every silly operation procedure would take a Ticket, followed by 1 st level escalation, then a 2nd escalation. Nothing works as a profesional environment. If you are in middle managment - watchout.( it becomes annoying beyond a point ) ( In a while you get used to it, however, its a skill which you woulnd need elsewhere) HR is redefined - designation counts in everything. It used to be a forem where you can voice out and action was taken. now dont even dream. if you are an associate escalating a AM, AM wins. if you are an AM escalating about an M, then M wins. (AM- Assistant Manager, M - Manager) HYD- they have a new facility in pocharam, now thats a bit far for most folks, so watch out where you would be placed. (Its a highway and rediculous traffic - Few fatalities reported) - best advise is use the company bus from uppal. Get water bottles to office, apparently cups are very expensive to provide (this is where it reaches the heights of cost cutting) - or those who have been to US, know in US offices they dont have cups either, but a water dispenser from which you can direclty drink. That equipments costs. and hence .... you know what am going to say. New applicants - be patient with HR (They are under a tremendrous stress) coz they had to recruit almost 365 days. they come across to u very rude most times and pretty unprofessional. coz the attrition is really healthy. Cant really blame the First line HR. Pity. Finally - Before taking a carrier decision please talk to an employee who is atlest 4 years in the organisation and a close friend. Those who read reviews, please take a min and give your inputs aswell. It really does help. Thank you Advice to Management Its a shame, look back 6 years and follow what you used to do, would be an impeccable company to work for.
title: Information which May help your Carrier in Genpact - All the best (Specific to BPO and KPO Not IT)

All that matter here is client satisfaction. So if you can satisfy your customer and make them happy by spoiling your health and personal life, you will be worshiped...yes just worshiped, do not expect any promotion or salary raise. -> This is may be specific to their IT division, but resource manager gives no consideration on allocating resources to a project. If you are available and there is a opening you will be allocated doesn't matter if that is you area of expertise or not and then you will be expected to perform as an expert else you will be rated as 'D'. -> Horrible compensation structure. At same level, your colleague at same level or even with inferior skill set than you might be getting double than you. You need to bargain for everything with HR..especially when you are traveling for company work. Advice to Management -> Reduce bureaucracy and number of managers and heavy weight HR layer. -> Get leaders who are smart and intelligent rather than just filling up post of Managers and AVPs -> Improve compensation structure. text: Pros The company transport system known as "Wheels".This was the only efficient efficient process.But I heard they have outsourced that completely to a vendor and they now pay Rs 1600 to employees who don't use that. Good for growth if you want to a low earning manager or AVP. Cons Lowest pay if you started out here or have been here too long.If you are joining with experience you need to bargain hard. There is no fixed salary structure and you may get your desired remuneration if the process is desperate to fill positions.Be rest assured that the folks who interview you would have no clue about the technology they talk about.Once you are in, any future hike is a mirage and is only based on the time spent and closeness to you manager and not on capabilities. Company promotes you instead of giving hikes.They take pride in the fact that they promote 1 employee a day on an average.There are too many managers and AVPs with low pay scales due to this policy. Company promotes BPO managers and appoints them in Technology processes screwing up any leadership and technology mentoring scope for the team members.The BPO managers call themselves techies based on the fact that they worked in a Outlook or desktop help desk which is considered very techie by BPO standards.You will crave for technology work but will find managers and AVPs in abundance. You will feel misplaced the moment you step in if you are a technology guy since the atmosphere is pure call center like or a B grade college canteen with youngsters (mostly call center folks) running around shouting and screaming. HR policies are mostly BPO centric which means no night shift , weekend or on call allowances. Company does not use basic IT components such as pager alerting for Technology folks who do on call and you need to be in front of your system (especially on weekend nights ) all the time looking for alerts. There is no attendance system in place and you are totally at the mercy of your manager to prove that you were indeed at work on a particular day.If you are close to your manager , you don't need to apply for any leaves taken at all in the leave tracking system. The managers don't have clue about technology since they were former BPO employees and provide no buffer between the client and the engineers.I had joined with an outside experience of around 5 years in a newly formed team and was surprised to find the manager's salary was less than most of the engineers in the team due to skewed HR remuneration policies. A team of 10 will have no less than 4 managers since the company wants to fit it the newly managers created by their "more promotion and less hike" policies.This may work out for the BPO folks well since you can find many 21 year old managers too in the company.This is due to the fact that they tie up with local Universities and hire folks from first year graduation on a 3 day work 3 day college program.This works out as cheap hiring and saves company costs. Employees are eligible for on site opportunities after 18 months of joining at a peanut remuneration of $30-40 a day since most of the call center crowd are dreamy eyed about the US. Six Sigma and Lean are some of the buzz words here used by folks to show off their non-existent capabilities. Work is mostly night shifts (without allowances) due to the US based clients so beware if you have a wife and kids at home.Your social life would go in for a full toss.If you happen to work day ( in case you are very lucky to get such a team ) you will find a deserted look in office since most of the teams work nights. On boarding is a nightmare and you be herded like cattle since the company has walk in practically every week for it BPO operations due to the high attrition rate. Tech folks aren't treated any different from BPO freshers. Advice to Management Stop doing technology work and focus on BPO.I guess that would make it a better company.
title: Confusion and fire fighting at its best.Nightmare for IT folks.Maybe good for BPO folks.

text: Pros Basis faciliteiten, zoals telefoons, laptops zijn op zich goed geregeld. Daarbij moet wel aangetekend worden dat deze expliciet niet voor prive gebruik bedoeld zijn. Cons Afspraken worden slecht nagekomen, of later aangepast in het nadeel van de werknemer. Bij het berekenen van facturabele uren (belangrijk voor bonus en verlengingen) worden niet altijd alle uren meegerekend. Managers zijn overbelast en daardoor slecht aanspreekbaar. Loonstroken en jaaroverzichten worden door Genpact als vertrouwelijk gekwalificeerd en mogen dus volgens de regels van Genpact niet naar een prive emailadres verzonden worden. (Uitprinten is ook ongewenst.) Als de regels netjes worden toegepast, staat er op het versturen van dergelijke documenten naar een prive emailadres, ontslag. Carrieremogelijkheden zijn er zeker, maar daarvoor geld wel dat er aan veel regels moet worden voldaan. Carriere maken omdat je gewoon goed bent in wat je doet is erg lastig. Er wordt verwacht dat je 20 uur per dag, 6 dagen per week bereikbaar bent. Als je een mailtje hebt gemist dat tussen 20:00 en 06:00 is verstuurd, wordt daar toch vreemd naar gekeken. Het bedrijf is volledig ingericht op normen en waarden die gebaseerd zijn op de (indische) wortels van het bedrijf. Dat wringt best wel eens in een (west) europesche setting. Advice to Management Luister veel beter naar de medewerkers. Zeker bij de consultingtak werken er meer mensen "ondanks alles" bij Genpact. Gezien de klantenkring is dat erg jammer. Neem eens afstand en vraag je dan af of dit nu echt de manier is waarop je je werk wilt doen.
